neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message:
nit: just for readability"
update_device_list(context=..., devices_up=[], devices_down=....)

We won't need to retry those ports again, or at least we can't set then as "removed" because those ports have been deleted and added in this polling cycle. Thus I'm not sure about adding them to "failed_devices".

If OVS agent has problems retrieving the information for a specific "readded" port, it will be marked too as failed_devices['added'].

It will be reported in the painpoints etherpad for sure 😜

(https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/pain-point-elimination#L274 )
This line will be only logged when there are some re_added ports. So it shouldn't be many lines added really.

def register_image(self, image_service, context, image_id, uri, location_metadata,     dest_name, src_name, clone_snap, dest_pool):

plugins/modules/server_action.py.message: "_Whether_ to search for server _in_ all projects..."?

find_server has no option to search in all projects and thus will only search in current project. For example, replace it with something like:

  server = self.conn.compute.get_server(server=os_server.id)

Or

  server = self.conn.compute.servers(name=self.params['server'], all_projects=self.params['all_projects'])

Or maybe we can even get rid of the whole api call and just use os_server object in wait_for_server?
Okay, looks like passing os_server directly that did not work 🙈
See my previous comment about find_server please. It only searches in current project. Use get_server or servers instead.

In my testing it finds all servers if the argument is a server UUID. If the argument is a server name you are right and it only search in the current project. So I think the current version is correct.

As I tried to clarify in the code comment, get_server is not applicable as it returns the wrong kind of object. An alternative would be to use
self.conn.compute.servers(name=self.params['server'], all_projects=True)

But that looks less efficient as it probably has to search through all servers.

Is there an easy way to add a test using two projects or would I have to extend the tests to setup multiple projects?

> In my testing it finds all servers if the argument is a server UUID. If the argument is a server name you are right and it only search in the current project. So I think the current version is correct.

How can it be correct, if it does not respect the all_projects keyword in this case? If the user specifies a server name from a server in a different project, sets all_projects to true and wait to true, then the user expects the module to wait until the server reaches the desired state. Without handling this case in _wait(), the server will not be found and the code might return before the server has reached the desired state.

> As I tried to clarify in the code comment, get_server is not applicable as it returns the wrong kind of object.

My proposal to pass os_server to wait_for_server directly was flawed, because os_server comes from self.conn.get_server (SDK's cloud layer). You are correct in that it does not return a Server object which is what wait_for_server expects. But my other two suggestions use SDK's proxy layer which indeed do return Server objects.

Ref.: https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/proxies/compute.html

> An alternative would be to use
> self.conn.compute.servers(name=self.params['server'], all_projects=True)

Yes, this is similar to what i suggested previously, but please do not use all_projects=True but all_projects=self.params['all_projects'] instead.

> But that looks less efficient as it probably has to search through all servers.

Probably true, I would prefer this instead:

  server = self.conn.compute.get_server(server=os_server.id)

The difference from the current code is hard to spot: It uses self.conn.compute.get_server (SDK proxy layer) instead of self.conn.get_server (SDK cloud layer).

Ref.: https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/proxies/compute.html

> Is there an easy way to add a test using two projects or would I have to extend the tests to setup multiple projects?

CI jobs install devstack instances including default projects in keystone. For example, look at each successful ci job output, go to 'Logs' tab and then navigate to controller > logs > etc > openstack > clouds.yaml, there you will find something like this:

https://e1b18cfae082c482941d-9c3ff8aa7dcabcee88b15fa3c77a7faa.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/830871/4/check/ansible-collections-openstack-functional-devstack-releases/afd91e7/controller/logs/etc/openstack/clouds.yaml

A nice overview can be find in devstack's sources:

https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/commit/14779fc992a7df41e6a1a093bf2aa4a7d248a6bd/lib/keystone#L275

And yes, please add tests!!! 😊👍

Forget about my first paragraph. You are right, we already have a UUID from os_server. I blame the night for this oversight, sorry 🙈

Tests would be great though 😊

I did not fully understand the difference between the cloud layer and proxy layer before. I changed the code to use `get_server` from the proxy layer with the UUID as argument as this does not support `all_projects` either. I think this is the cleanest solution as it directly gets the server by UUID instead of doing a search.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This change does not solve the referenced bug. As discussed in channel the bug was originally a little misleading as at first reading it seemed to ask for specific masakarimonitor config options to be exposed by the charm. However, it actually was asking for the charm to support the config-flags charm option which allows for arbitrary config do be added to a config file. As I mentioned I update the bug to clarify this. I believe the way to resolve this bug is to add the config-flags charm option to config.yaml, update the charm to read those options and add them to a context which can be for rendering templates and finally add the masakarimonitors.conf template to render those options passed via config flags

src/config.yaml.message: The bug is requesting that you add the `config-flags` charm option, not that you explicitly add these options which are not supported by the charm as they relates to the process monitor which the charm is not intended to support

zuul/driver/sql/sqlconnection.py.message:
I'm on the fence about this:

While it's true that this can add some protection to using a broken connection, because we only keep idle connections for 1 second, it would only protect us in the situation where:

* We sucessfully used a connection less than a second ago.
* The connection has broken since then.
* The connection will be automatically fixed within sqlalchemy's 3 retry attempts (I'm not sure how long that is).

There isn't much overhead to this change, but there's some, and maybe it's not worth the vanishingly small chance that it actually helps?

On the other hand, maybe we can make the reporting handling more robust so that it doesn't have cascading failure effects.
Agreed. Let's make the reporting more robust before considering this again.

thank you for the feedback! yeah, it may vary, the list contains only the default ones - in case user didn't set specific extensions - in case a user wants to enable more extensions (or different subset of them) it can be done via NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS var which will override DEFAULT_NET_EXT one.

Extensions:

security-groups-shared-filtering
security-groups-normalized-cidr
quota-check-limit

are supported by ML2 plugin so will be available in any configuration for sure and can be added here as default extensions.

Everything else what You mentioned are extensions which can be enabled by enabling some service plugin (qos, segments, portforwardings, logging, trunk), extension drivers (dns integration) or config option (vlan-transparent). So I wouldn't add them to the list of default extensions.

Also that list of default extensions can vary depending on the backend (ML2/OVN or something else) used. So maybe it would be good to prepare list based on the Q_AGENT variable? But that can be done as follow-up patch for sure.

If you compare with xena, we had added there

DEFAULT_NET_EXT+=",multiple-external-gateways,qos-pps-minimum,l3-ext-ndp-proxy,rbac-bgpvpn"
DEFAULT_NET_EXT+=",qos-pps,ecmp_routes,bgp,floating-ip-port-forwarding-port-ranges"

Yes, but as always there is a trade off here. Size of a complete set of images with shared layers, vs. size of a complete set of images without shared layers. By removing these packages you are optimising for the latter, at the expense of the former.

Bug added. I haven't found docs that are in need of critical update with this addition.

Nicely handled! Just to raise discussion: another possible solution would be to only watch for Pod events and make sure the KuryrPort CRD is fetched right before handling the event. I don't have a strong opinion about it.

BTW, regarding the docs, maybe a small note can be added here about the new watcher
https://docs.openstack.org/kuryr-kubernetes/latest/devref/kuryr_kubernetes_design.html#cni-daemon

The problem with that approach is - what do we do if KuryrPort is not there? Do we wait and repeat the call? Do we fail the CNI call? What if UID doesn't match? Do we wait? Do we drop the request? I'm not sure if this solves much comparing to the present approach.

A simpler approach is taken by ovn-kube, it's just waiting while polling until everything is set up by the the main service. The thing is that for us it's not much else than waiting for an event IMO.

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/handlers.py.message: Not really, this is just a regular event when we've just got a new ADD or MODIFIED KuryrPort event, so it's not deleted yet.

Oh, even more interestingly, in case we get CNI_DELETED_POD_SENTINEL here, this should never be called as KuryrPort never got created, so certainly we shouldn't rely on deleting it here. It doesn't hurt to just make sure we're not touching anything if it's a sentinel though.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I do think this is reducing our security posture, the restriction imposed on untrusted jobs may not be perfect, but they provide an extra layer to prevent remote code execution on the executor instances.

If I understand correctly, this spec has a significant impact for operators, thus if we can improve the compartmentalizations along the way that may be worth the effort. For example, it seems like nodeless job may cause a "noisy neighbor" effect resulting in a negative impact.

That being said, I am in favor of this spec because the benefits outweigh the risk.

doc/source/developer/specs/unrestricted-.message: Is it possible for Zuul to install an ansible core + limited batteries included to more closely match 2.9? Would that simplify things enough to be a possibility?

Yes.  But then we are curating our own Ansible distribution, and we have to do the work to qualify the collections that we install.  We would have to install several to obtain the basic level of functionality we expect.

Even if we don't accept this proposal, I think we should use Ansible community so that we continue to approximate what "install ansible" means to people.

However, if we don't accept this proposal, we may want to consider going the other direction and say since we're not going to have a fully-functional Ansible anyway, let's reduce the functionality further and maybe install fewer collections so that we don't support everything we have now in 2.9.  That might be a win for maintainability.

Another approach to consider (especially regarding your concerns below) would be to lift the file/network access permissions from our restricted ansible and try to only focus on limiting untrusted execution.  That might further reduce the scope of work (we would still need to figure out how to override the new collections loading mechanism, but at least then we would have far fewer plugins to try to override).
That is the good point about diverging from what people expect from Ansible.

I will not speak for Zuul's ability to do that or not but it is an intended use case to be able to install just ansible-core and then cherry-pick the collections that users are interested in.

There's a galaxy requirements file that is available and kept up to date based on the collections that are included in the latest release of the ``ansible`` package from which you can remove the things you don't have a use for: https://github.com/ansible-community/ansible-build-data/blob/main/5/galaxy-requirements.yaml

It may be worth noting that the linux kernel has had several such bugs in the last ~month. I think operators would have to consider immediately shutting down Zuul to patch things like the kernel when these local privilege escalation bugs are disclosed.

We have always tried to patch quickly anyway, but the added layer of protection gives us some breathing room which has been nice.

Additionally rotating credentials is a very expensive endeavor now that executors can talk to zookeeper.

These two things combined make me wary of this change. Executors have more access than ever and linux is seeing major exploits right now.

My initial thought on this is that if the change were made OpenDev should consider not driving CD through Zuul any more. To decouple the risk of executors from the rest of the system more fully. Maybe run a secondary small zuul just for this instead with restricted access? Haven't fully thought this through.

The original idea of Zuul v3 was simple: use your production Ansible playbooks in testing and run both directly from Zuul.  That's why Nodesets are Ansible inventory, etc.  You just swap one for the other.

The restricted Ansible environment prevents us from achieving that because an untrusted playbook can't use enough of Ansible to actually directly execute a real production playbook.  Generally this is solved by nesting Ansible.  At this point, it hardly matters what Zuul itself is running.  It's just a multi-node execution coordinator that happens to implement a subset of Ansible.

So the motivation to do this to improve the CD story is to get back to that original idea: just have Zuul run Ansible.

An OpenDev-like system could just "run: playbooks/eavesdrop.yaml" using the built-in ssh keys, etc, and not have to worry about anything else.  Now, OpenDev itself may still not end up doing that because of logs and a desire to run things from bridge.  But the potential is there, and anyone without OpenDev's concerns about logs might be more comfortable with it.

OpenDev could certainly directly execute simple playbooks like tenant reconfiguration loading, or publishing meeting calendars, or other similar event-driven CD things where the unique requirements aren't present.

If we're inclined to accept the risk and accept this proposal, then I think that's the story.  If we are not inclined, then I think the CD story becomes "Zuul runs a tiny subset of mostly-compatible-Ansible that you use to bootstrap whatever it is you want to use to CD, but you'll need an external node.  More or less what we have today, but you've got me thinking that if we can't fully use Ansible then maybe we should minimize it even more and start really pushing the angle that Zuul's Ansible is only there to bootstrap stuff.

This change has two benefits: 1) it reduces the amount of holes we have to try to find and plug every time there is a new Ansible; and 2) it makes CD directly from Zuul more viable.

If we don't think that improves the CD story, then that removes that benefit and makes this much less compelling.

Personally (as I noted at the bottom) I think the current protection is so weak as to be nearly nonexistent, but I do agree it is something, and it may take someone a little longer to figure out how to run something on the executor.

A determined attacker of course would find and sit on a Zuul restriction bypass until they obtained the local root exploit so they could use them simultaneously.
Tristan, yes, a successful exploit would get access to ZK and therefore all Zuul secrets.

Where the CD story becomes problematic for me is the exposure level in using Zuul for CD. With layers of security in theory our exposure is more limited. If we remove one layer of protection we become more exposed potentially.

I think it may be worth expanding on the impact of CD on changes like this and how we can do better in general. Perhaps we can couple the ansible changes with stronger improvements in other areas to make CD more viable.
I agree this is a major concern, would a successful exploit get access to all the secrets known to Zuul?
I think it was GKE that basically gives you full cluster root if you have access to this by default. Might be worth explicitly calling out known cases where this is a problem?
Yeah, wouldn't hurt to list specific examples.

I think there are more things we can do (and maybe that operators could do independent of us), but I think that most of the network and filesystem risks are actively manageable right now.  Even in most corporate environments, I don't think being able to winrm from the zuul executor is a big concern.  It seems like the local root exploit is the most concerning to you, so if we want to keep the "no-untrusted-exec" requirement, I don't think this is feasible.

(Also, FWIW, I think we were happy to rely on only the restricted Ansible when we started v3 development; bwrap was a nice extra benefit, and then we realized it's actually doing most of the work.)
I worry that assuming selinux/apparmor in Zuul assumes too much about deploymont.  We could run bwrap as a secondary user, as long as it doesn't entail giving the executor more privileges.

Thinking about this from a defense in depth perspective are we able to leverage bwrap to restrict activity a bit more? For example could we restrict network connectivity to ssh/winrm/etc ports in untrusted contexts? Maybe limit system capabilites if we have room there as well?

Mostly thinking out loud here as I don't think we ever wanted to rely on any single defense mechanism and instead layer them to ensure as much safety as possible.

Maybe Selinux or apparmor or similar would be useful here too?

Yes, I think the major concerns I've got are a privilege escalation on the executor and possibly a container escape given executor's zk access.

Thinking about zk access a bit I wonder if we can/should run the bwrap processes as a secondary user. And possibly something like selinux/apparmor can restrict file access further.

I agree that existing deployments could probably do more alongside Zuul, but not needing to do that lifting separately in every deployment and instead share it via common zuul expectations and deployment tooling would go a long way I think.

It is likely impossible for a container to change it's context after it started, so that may not be useful for executor already running a container. Also this may be difficult to setup as it depends a lot on the host system configuration.
Mea culpa!
This is not exactly accurate, the upstream end of life for Ansible 2.9 is currently planned for May 2022: https://groups.google.com/g/ansible-announce/c/kegIH5_okmg/

As a quick example: a git mirroring job that just needs to "git push" from the executor.  I'm sure there are better ones, but most zero-node jobs that actually do anything need to have trusted playbooks at this point.
Is it really a hindrance for lightweight jobs, do we have example?

FWIW: Ansible 5.5.0 was released last week -- the current pace of release for the 'ansible' package is a minor release every 3 weeks and a major release every 6 months (which aligns with the 6 months cycle of ansible-core).

Ansible 6.0.0 is currently expected in May 2022 which aligns with the new release of ansible-core planned at the same time, 2.13.
Should we consider leveraging execution environment https://docs.ansible.com/automation-controller/latest/html/userguide/execution_environments.html?

That could be an interesting way to use Ansible within Zuul, though since it's essentially building and running a container it's sort of parallel to what we're doing with bwrap.  We might even consider it a replacement for bwrap at some point, but I think we can defer that for now since I think fundamentally the security issues are the same.

Execution environments are container images built with ansible-builder (https://github.com/ansible/ansible-builder) and they're meant to contain particular versions of ansible-core, ansible-runner as well as Ansible collections necessary for the users' playbooks.

If you're curious to see what it looks like in practice, I have a simple example here which adds the ansible and ara packages on top of a "base" execution environment: https://github.com/ansible-community/images/tree/main/execution-environments

ansible-navigator is a TUI that, amongst other things, knows about execution environments and can run playbooks with them.
I wasn't aware of list-tasks, it looks interesting, but after a quick check, it looks like it doesn't recurse into include_role.

I wonder if we could implement the restriction using static analysis instead. Before running an unstrusted playbook, perhaps we could manually inspect its content to iterate over its tasks and prevent forbidden usage? When a task is not iterable, for example if it includes a dynamically generated tasks, then we could fail by default?

That seems like a distinct possibility.  We might miss something, but we miss things with our current system too.

I worry that we might spend a long time figuring out all the possible ways of including tasks.  :)

Are the only ways to include tasks: roles, include, include_tasks, import_tasks and  import_playbooks ?

I think the main issue is implementing the semantic of jinja variable precedences, but that can be done.

I don't think this is feasible for us zuul maintainers. Such a static analysis sounds like it would require an entire project with several people maintaining this. To me this sounds like even more work like we have to do with the current approach.

Perhaps this does not have to be implemented within zuul, and maybe that could be useful to others. For example, the `--list-task` argument of ansible-playbook seems promising, but it might need some tweak to be useful here.

If such a static analysis tool existed, then it seems like we would be able to use ansible without modification, while preserving the restriction for untrusted playbook.
Perhaps we should consider CPU and memory resources?
Yes; the ability to run more zero-node jobs will probably increase CPU and memory pressure.
What about resources exhaustion, is there something we should do to prevent one job to hog all the resources?
Good point.  This is an excellent example of how we may think we are more protected than we really are.
Maybe we can note that e.g. the ansible uri module is already now available for local execution so everything that can be done with the uri module is already possible without this change.
This is already possible via the uri module (this is unrestricted).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
On initial review, there are some things that need addressing in the current patch proposed and that feedback is provided as in-line comments.

However, that being said - I have larger concerns about using the mysql-admin interface for monitoring purposes. The mysql-admin interface is intentionally there to provide ALL privileges to a user which I think we want to be careful about when we use it.

I think what is called for here is access to allow a remote user to have read-only type access for monitoring purposes. While I appreciate that the mysql-admin interface has been used for other charms for this sake of monitoring, I think this is an anti-pattern which we should not perpetuate to this charm. Yes, it means more work to create the proper interfaces and such, however I think it is more secure and we should default for this position when possible.

I recognize that there may be a proper use case for providing the mysql-admin interface in this charm, however the currently described use case does not warrant such unfettered access and I am strongly against including this interface for the purpose described.

Hey Billy,

I think interfaces, especially the ones in layer-index should be reused as much as possible. While I understand the "mysql-root" interface has a purpose (meant to grant elevated privs), I think the "mysql" interface should be enough. Basically, they both do the same and expose the same attributes, but they have been given purpose (which I personally think is wrong).

There is an interesting example around the "http" interface, used by charm-prometheus in different ways. The idea about interfaces is that they shared an agreed number of attributes (and their values), and then each side of the relation decides how to use that information. In Prometheus, the "http" info is used to configure targets, or alertmanagers.

In this charm, I think the "mysql" interface should be used, with an endpoint such as "mysql-monitor", which generates an unprivileges/read-only user for monitoring purposes. I don't think a new interface should be created (ideally, a single interface should have been created for admin, root, unprivileged cases, since it's up to the endpoint on what to do... but I agree the documentation in the "mysql-root" would be misguiding if used).

What do you think about using the "mysql" interface?

Note: as a downside, charm-telegraf will need to be updated to use that new interface (but the endpoint would behave in the same way as the "mysql" [1] one).

1. https://git.launchpad.net/charm-telegraf/tree/src/metadata.yaml#n65

In case we still want to create a new interface here is PR [1].

I think if `get_db_helper` (there is TODO for that in code) is
generalized, this interface could handle creating read-only users.

---
[1]: https://github.com/r-f-g/interface-mysql-monitor/pull/1

Okay, I agree with your opinion and I'll create such a new interface.

I'll use the name `mysql-monitor` and I'll get back to this review when it's done.

I definitely agree that it is not necessary to have write access for monitoring, it never occurred to me to check it before, as mysql-root also requires a database as parameter in this function [1].

I modified the function for creating a cluster user, where it is possible to add it with read only access, ie privileges such as SELECT and SHOW VIEW.

---
[1]: https://github.com/juju-solutions/interface-mysql-root/blob/master/provides.py#L50

We shouldn't use the mysql-admin interface, as the contract provided in that interface is to provide full admin level access - e.g. from the documentation "The mysql-root interface is meant to grant elevated privileges for a MySQL user."

This is decidedly not that and as such a new interface needs to be created to support this that conveys the intention. The new interface can take into appropriate consideration for what is needed, e.g. read access without requiring a new database be created, etc.
Thank you for the review. I left inline-comments.

These changes are blocked until the interface-mysql-monitor [1] it's not ready.

---
[1]: https://github.com/r-f-g/interface-mysql-monitor
This is blocked until there is no new interface for monitoring purpose.

This is blocked until mysql-monitor is not part of layer-index <==> [1] is merged.

---
[1]: https://github.com/juju/layer-index/pull/121
Thanks for review. I add function, which will handle granting (revoke all and than grant new privileges) privileges for uses.
Thanks for working through this Robert. Everything looks reasonably in order here.

src/reactive/mysql_innodb_cluster_handle.message: If this fails, is it something that the charm will recover from naturally or does it require administrator intervention? This feels like a hard failure not just a warning.

If this is not successful, than the `db_admin.provide_database` will be not called and the flag `db-admin.database.requested` will be not removed [1]. So I decided not to use another flag for it.

I think there is a chance that it will be a serious failure, but most likely not.

[1]: https://github.com/juju-solutions/interface-mysql-root/blob/d33d344885baf5b5f3d208b34c887a89a38e5631/provides.py#L72
I don't believe you actually want a database anyways, but are bound by the requirements of the interface.
I think we want this to be dependent on the remote application name, not just a hard coded db-admin as that will share credentials with all applications related over this mysql-admin interface.
I agree that could be serious a problem.

While the WARNING log is sufficient here, the create_cluster_user will only log a warning if the user already exists. I'm debating whether the permissions should be checked in that case as a user could be given credentials which are intended to be read-only (from the relation) but then receive an escalation of privileges since the user already exists w/ admin credentials. I think we should *probably* guard against this in the create_cluster_user code.

Due to the fact that the user is not deleted after the removing of the relation, this is a good idea. I add function, which will handle granting privileges for users.
I tested usage of `WITH GRANT OPTION` and the result are here [1].

---
[1]: https://pastebin.canonical.com/p/4758bCyD28/
I think that's a reasonable approach

Hi Billy, there is a `_grant_cluster_user_privileges` function that will ensure that the user has the correct privileges by deleting all current privileges and then adding read-only/ALL privileges. This function is called when the user is created and also when it already exists.

What do you think? Is this enough?

Steps to boot secure boot enabled image:

On build host:
1) Update repo
2) Edit image yaml, set `EFI_SECURE_BOOT: enable'
3) Rebuild lat container
$ cd /data/hjia/stx/debianbuild/tools
$ . ./import-stx
$ ./stx-init-env --rebuild
4) Build image
$ stx control enter 
$ build-image -t std

On target:
5) Enter BIOS, remove existed certs of EFI secure boot
6) Boot from ISO or PXE, insert LAT debian certs for EFI secure
boot and reboot, all done automatically

  Booting `Automatic Certificate Provision'

Platform is in Setup Mode

Created db Cert

Platform is in User Mode
Platform is set to boot securely
Prepare to execute system warm reset after 3 seconds ...

7) Enter BIOS again, enable EFI secure boot, save configuration and reboot
8) Do secure boot installation, all done automatically
